999511015791280128.text: The L0pht seven has become a legend in the hacker's community, very much like the magnificent seven to the cowboys in the Wild West.

999743008370118656.text: 20 years on, L0pht hackers (@dotMudge @spacerog @joegrand @WeldPond) return to Capitol Hill with dire warnings (moderated by @k8em0) https://www.the-parallax.com/2018/05/24/l0pht-hackers-return-dire-warnings/ … by @robpegoraro #l0pht20

999658035923636224.text:
“We were the hackers using our outsider, attacker perspective to try to make changes." @weldpond

Time, and the L0pht, March On https://decipher.sc/time-and-the-l0pht-march-on … #decipher #deciphersec

999180274205364224.text: I don't think something like the original #l0pht hearing would be possible today. Politics at that time understood the need for open dialogue about critical infrastructure. 20years later its all litigation and 0day #l0pht20  The hearing video should be mandatory for every1 in IT

999043446840156165.text: Key points from @dotMudge, @spacerog, @WeldPond, @joegrand: Things have improved (e.g., companies don't automatically resent vuln reports, Win 10 is so much better than Win NT); it's still too hard to shop for secure products; some laws continue to menace security research.

999327618729218049.text: Vendor's squelching researchers and disclosure doesn't make the problem or vulnerability go away. It simply makes it a ticking timebomb for an attacker, nation state, others or competitor to use to their advantage. #l0pht20

999028282665390081.text: “Angering a bunch of security researchers is like inviting a swarm of bees to your picnic” - @k8em0 in response to a vendor example of squelching researchers and disclosure #l0pht20pic.twitter.com/RtNOycdd9h

999023625608007681.text: So @joegrand easily got the most audience laughs, if anyone's counting. #l0pht20

999024364283670528.text: On finding better ways to tell vendors their babies are ugly (i.e. their products are insecure): "Once my friend told me my baby looked like an alien and I thought that was pretty cool." @joegrand #l0pht20

999023762166214663.text: While quoting Trump about his lack of updating his phones highlighted recently... eschewed security for convenience. Is there something to learn here? Can we do better? Is this the last hill to storm in our quest for a happy ending? #L0pht20 @joegrand

999022284907208705.text: Let's stop pointing fingers at engineers and hold the vendors themselves to higher standards. @joegrand #l0pht20

999022571319328770.text: Hah... @joegrand says (in away) engineers and developers tend to do “copypasta” from examples, demos and reference architecture and designs. Requires vendors to do better with documentation - and emphasize security. This is how some of the bad gets in. #L0pht20

999021027798781952.text: Some things have gotten better since 20 years ago, but nearly all of the same vulnerability classes are still there. @joegrand #l0pht20

999022014261276673.text: Why are things so bad? Most people either know security or engineering. There's not enough crossover. @joegrand #l0pht20

999020165521117184.text: Diversity of perspective is essential to the security community; ‘you can’t have one homogeneous mindset.’ – @joegrand #L0pht20

999021597745872902.text: Consumer IoT is a new and weird animal – low resource, virtually indefensible devices being connected to the Internet by the million, for some reason. – @joegrand #L0pht20

999021982363672576.text: The “low hanging fruit” on hardware platforms (due to poor design and rigor) still exist today and don’t require complex attacks. #L0pht20 @joegrand (don’t blame the engineers, they are trained in engineering but not security - cross training or partnerships with security)

999020592216117253.text: .@joegrand: securing things is really hard; important to train people about how hackers think #l0pht20pic.twitter.com/5OXDER1hH5

999020683861557250.text: Touching on #STEM education and awareness and hardware... getting the holistic view on the entire product environment... better to understand what you have to protect. @joegrand #L0pht20

999017761551671296.text: “The numbers of software (and systems) with good security is still incredibly small”... even after 20 years. Standards and certifications “are what *feel* right”...but are there ways to differentiate the good from the bad? @dotMudge #l0pht20 (software bill of materials?!)

999025954478542854.text: Focus on incremental improvements rather than thinking any piece of legislation can be a silver bullet. "Let's go from crappy to slightly less crappy." @WeldPond #l0pht20

999014974440828928.text: "Over about 10 years it went from 'please go away' to 'thank you, here's some money'." @WeldPond #l0pht20

999014679979622400.text: "It took the industry years to come to terms with outsiders poking holes in their systems." @WeldPond #l0pht20pic.twitter.com/dIemYBvUS7

999014472688816129.text: .@WeldPond: back in 1998, we were outsiders and we were curious; our hacker mentality helped us find insecurities that the vendors didn’t think about #l0pht20 #cybersecuritypic.twitter.com/oNUIRfY5Fh

999026268552286208.text: As we went from mainframe/thin client to server/desktop to cloud/mobile to IoT/wearable/implantable/ubiquitous connectivity, we repeat the same mistakes and have to relearn the same lessons. @spacerog #L0pht20

999012994590871553.text: Quick summary from @spacerog for #l0pht20 - it’s gotten worse (more tech, more complexity, more mistakes) but gotten better (more information, more visibility, better understanding)pic.twitter.com/XFA01GNCeD

999000585079853056.text: Getting ready to revisit #l0pht20 with @joe grand and @dotMudgepic.twitter.com/4uVfjbARwo
